subcommands.description: Display commands that pertain to kubernetes 1-click applications

options.description: A comma-separated list of 1-click applications to install on the Kubernetes cluster. Use the `doctl kubernetes 1-click list` command for a list of available 1-click applications.
Enables automatic upgrades to new patch releases during the cluster's maintenance window. Defaults to false. To enable automatic upgrade, supply `--auto-upgrade=true`.

The CIDR block to use for the pod network. Must be a valid CIDR block. Defaults to 10.244.0.0/16. If left empty/default the cluster will be created with a virtual network. If a custom one is provided, the cluster will be created as vpc-native cluster. VPC-native CIDR blocks cannot overlap within an account.
A comma-separated list of allowed addresses that can access the control plane.
The number of nodes in the default node pool (incompatible with --node-pool) (default 3)
Creates the cluster with amd gpu device metrics exporter plugin installed. Defaults to false. To enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-metrics-exporter-plugin=true.
Creates the cluster with amd gpu device plugin installed. Defaults to true for clusters with AMD GPUs and otherwise false. To always enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-plugin=true.
Creates the cluster with control plane firewall enabled. Defaults to false. To enable the control plane firewall, supply --enable-control-plane-firewall=true.
Creates the cluster with routing-agent enabled. Defaults to false. To enable routing-agent, supply --enable-routing-agent=true.

Customizes expanders used by cluster-autoscaler. The autoscaler will apply each expander from the provided comma-separated list to narrow down the selection of node types created to scale up, until either a single node type is left, or the list of expanders is exhausted. Available expanders: random, least-waste, priority. If this flag is empty, autoscaler will use its default expanders.
Creates the cluster with a highly-available control plane. Defaults to false. To enable the HA control plane, supply --ha=true.

Sets the beginning of the schedule for the four hour maintenance window for the cluster. The syntax format is: `day=HH:MM`, where time is in UTC. Day can be: `any`, `monday`, `tuesday`, `wednesday`, `thursday`, `friday`, `saturday`, `sunday`. (default "any=00:00")
A comma-separated list of node-pools, defined using semicolon-separated configuration values and surrounded by quotes (incompatible with --size and --count).
A slug indicating which region to create the cluster in. Use the `doctl kubernetes options regions` command for a list of options (required) (default "nyc1")

The unneed time for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-unneeded-time. It defines how long a node should be unneeded before it is eligible for scale down. To set the scale-down-unneeded-time to a minute and 30 seconds for example, pass the string '1m30s'.

The threshold value for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-utilization-threshold. It is the maximum value between the sum of CPU requests and sum of memory requests of all pods running on the node divided by node's corresponding allocatable resource, below which a node can be considered for scale down. To set the scale-down-utilization-threshold to 50%, pass the floating point value 0.5.

The CIDR block to use for the service network. Must be a valid CIDR block. Defaults to 10.245.0.0/16. If left empty/default the cluster will be created with a virtual network. If a custom one is provided, the cluster will be created as vpc-native cluster. VPC-native CIDR blocks cannot overlap within an account.
Sets the current kubectl context to that of the new cluster (default true)

The machine size to use when creating nodes in the default node pool (incompatible with --node-pool). Use the `doctl kubernetes options sizes` command for a list of possible values. (default "s-1vcpu-2gb-intel")
Enables surge-upgrade for the cluster (default true)
A comma-separated list of tags to apply to the cluster, in addition to the default tags of `k8s` and `k8s:$K8S_CLUSTER_ID`.
Adds a configuration context for the new cluster to your kubectl (default true)
A slug indicating which Kubernetes version to use when creating the cluster. Use the `doctl kubernetes options versions` command for a list of options (default "latest")

The UUID of a VPC network to create the cluster in. Must be the UUID of a valid VPC in the same region specified for the cluster. If a VPC is not specified, the cluster is placed in the default VPC network for the region.
Instructs the terminal to wait for the action to complete before returning control to the user (default true)

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster create
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates a Kubernetes cluster given the specified options and using the specified name. Before creating the cluster, you can use `doctl kubernetes options` to see possible values for the various configuration flags.

If no configuration flags are used, a three-node cluster with a single node pool is created in the `nyc1` region, using the latest Kubernetes version.

After creating a cluster, a configuration context is added to kubectl and made active so that you can begin managing your new cluster immediately.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster create <name> [flags]

Aliases:
  create, c

Examples:
The following example creates a cluster named `example-cluster` in the `nyc1` region with a node pool, using Kubernetes version `1.28.2-do.0`: doctl kubernetes cluster create example-cluster --region nyc1 --version 1.28.2-do.0 --maintenance-window saturday=02:00 --node-pool "name=example-pool;size=s-2vcpu-2gb;count=5;tag=web;tag=frontend;label=key1=value1;label=key2=label2;taint=key1=value1:NoSchedule;taint=key2:NoExecute"

Flags:
      --1-clicks applications                              A comma-separated list of 1-click applications to install on the Kubernetes cluster. Use the `doctl kubernetes 1-click list` command for a list of available 1-click applications.
      --auto-upgrade false                                 Enables automatic upgrades to new patch releases during the cluster's maintenance window. Defaults to false. To enable automatic upgrade, supply `--auto-upgrade=true`.
      --cluster-subnet 10.244.0.0/16                       The CIDR block to use for the pod network. Must be a valid CIDR block. Defaults to 10.244.0.0/16. If left empty/default the cluster will be created with a virtual network. If a custom one is provided, the cluster will be created as vpc-native cluster. VPC-native CIDR blocks cannot overlap within an account.
      --control-plane-firewall-allowed-addresses strings   A comma-separated list of allowed addresses that can access the control plane.
      --count int                                          The number of nodes in the default node pool (incompatible with --node-pool) (default 3)
      --enable-amd-gpu-device-metrics-exporter-plugin      Creates the cluster with amd gpu device metrics exporter plugin installed. Defaults to false. To enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-metrics-exporter-plugin=true.
      --enable-amd-gpu-device-plugin                       Creates the cluster with amd gpu device plugin installed. Defaults to true for clusters with AMD GPUs and otherwise false. To always enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-plugin=true.
      --enable-control-plane-firewall                      Creates the cluster with control plane firewall enabled. Defaults to false. To enable the control plane firewall, supply --enable-control-plane-firewall=true.
      --enable-routing-agent                               Creates the cluster with routing-agent enabled. Defaults to false. To enable routing-agent, supply --enable-routing-agent=true.
      --expanders strings                                  Customizes expanders used by cluster-autoscaler. The autoscaler will apply each expander from the provided comma-separated list to narrow down the selection of node types created to scale up, until either a single node type is left, or the list of expanders is exhausted. Available expanders: random, least-waste, priority. If this flag is empty, autoscaler will use its default expanders.
      --ha                                                 Creates the cluster with a highly-available control plane. Defaults to false. To enable the HA control plane, supply --ha=true.
  -h, --help                                               help for create
      --maintenance-window schedule                        Sets the beginning of the schedule for the four hour maintenance window for the cluster. The syntax format is: `day=HH:MM`, where time is in UTC. Day can be: `any`, `monday`, `tuesday`, `wednesday`, `thursday`, `friday`, `saturday`, `sunday`. (default "any=00:00")
      --node-pool node-pools                               A comma-separated list of node-pools, defined using semicolon-separated configuration values and surrounded by quotes (incompatible with --size and --count).
                                                           Format: `"name=your-name;size=size_slug;count=5;tag=tag1;tag=tag2;label=key1=value1;label=key2=label2;taint=key1=value1:NoSchedule;taint=key2:NoExecute"` where:
                                                           
                                                           - `name`: The name of the node pool, which must be unique in the cluster
                                                           - `size`: The machine size of the nodes to use. Use the `doctl kubernetes options sizes` command for a list of available options.
                                                           - `count`: The number of nodes to create
                                                           - `tag`: A comma-separated list of tags to apply to nodes in the pool
                                                           - `label`: A label in `key=value` notation. Repeat to add multiple labels at once.
                                                           - `taint`: Taint in `key=value:effect` notation. Repeat to add multiple taints at once.
                                                           - `auto-scale`: Enables cluster auto-scaling on the node pool (boolean).
                                                           - `min-nodes`: The minimum number of nodes that the cluster can be auto-scaled to. The value will be 0 if auto_scale is set to false. Scale-to-zero is not supported.
                                                           - `max-nodes`: The maximum number of nodes that can be auto-scaled to.
      --region slug                                        A slug indicating which region to create the cluster in. Use the `doctl kubernetes options regions` command for a list of options (required) (default "nyc1")
      --scale-down-unneeded-time string                    The unneed time for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-unneeded-time. It defines how long a node should be unneeded before it is eligible for scale down. To set the scale-down-unneeded-time to a minute and 30 seconds for example, pass the string '1m30s'.
      --scale-down-utilization-threshold string            The threshold value for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-utilization-threshold. It is the maximum value between the sum of CPU requests and sum of memory requests of all pods running on the node divided by node's corresponding allocatable resource, below which a node can be considered for scale down. To set the scale-down-utilization-threshold to 50%, pass the floating point value 0.5.
      --service-subnet 10.245.0.0/16                       The CIDR block to use for the service network. Must be a valid CIDR block. Defaults to 10.245.0.0/16. If left empty/default the cluster will be created with a virtual network. If a custom one is provided, the cluster will be created as vpc-native cluster. VPC-native CIDR blocks cannot overlap within an account.
      --set-current-context                                Sets the current kubectl context to that of the new cluster (default true)
      --size size                                          The machine size to use when creating nodes in the default node pool (incompatible with --node-pool). Use the `doctl kubernetes options sizes` command for a list of possible values. (default "s-1vcpu-2gb-intel")
      --surge-upgrade                                      Enables surge-upgrade for the cluster (default true)
      --tag tags                                           A comma-separated list of tags to apply to the cluster, in addition to the default tags of `k8s` and `k8s:$K8S_CLUSTER_ID`.
      --update-kubeconfig                                  Adds a configuration context for the new cluster to your kubectl (default true)
      --version slug                                       A slug indicating which Kubernetes version to use when creating the cluster. Use the `doctl kubernetes options versions` command for a list of options (default "latest")
      --vpc-uuid string                                    The UUID of a VPC network to create the cluster in. Must be the UUID of a valid VPC in the same region specified for the cluster. If a VPC is not specified, the cluster is placed in the default VPC network for the region.
      --wait                                               Instructs the terminal to wait for the action to complete before returning control to the user (default true)

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster delete
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Deletes the specified Kubernetes clusters and the Droplets associated with them. To delete all other DigitalOcean resources created during the operation of the clusters, such as load balancers, volumes or volume snapshots, use the `--dangerous` flag.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster delete <id|name>... [flags]

Aliases:
  delete, d, rm

Examples:
The following example deletes a cluster named `example-cluster`: doctl kubernetes cluster delete example-cluster

Flags:
      --dangerous           Deletes the cluster's associated resources like load balancers, volumes and volume snapshots
  -f, --force               Deletes the cluster without a confirmation prompt
  -h, --help                help for delete
      --update-kubeconfig   Remove the deleted cluster from your kubeconfig (default true)

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster delete-selective
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Deletes the specified Kubernetes cluster and Droplets associated with it. It also deletes the specified associated resources. Associated resources can be load balancers, volumes and volume snapshots.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster delete-selective <id|name> [flags]

Aliases:
  delete-selective, ds

Examples:
The following example deletes a cluster named `example-cluster` and selectively deletes the specified load balancers and volumes associated with the cluster: doctl kubernetes cluster delete-selective example-cluster --volume-list "386734086,example-volume" --load-balancer-list "191669331,example-load-balancer"

Flags:
  -f, --force                    Deletes the cluster without a confirmation prompt
  -h, --help                     help for delete-selective
      --load-balancers strings   A comma-separated list of load balancer IDs or names to delete
      --snapshots strings        A comma-separated list of volume snapshot IDs or names to delete
      --update-kubeconfig        Removes the deleted cluster from your kubeconfig (default true)
      --volumes strings          A comma-separated list of volume IDs or names to delete

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster get
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Retrieves the following details about a Kubernetes cluster: 

- A unique ID for the cluster
- A human-readable name for the cluster
- The slug identifying the region where the Kubernetes cluster is located
- The slug identifying the cluster's Kubernetes version. If set to a minor version, the latest patch version for that minor version is returned. For example, if the cluster is set to  `1.14`, the command would return `1.14.6-do.1`. If it is set to `latest`, the latest published version is used.
- A boolean value indicating whether the cluster automatically upgrades to new patch releases during its maintenance window.
- An object containing a "state" attribute whose value is set to a string indicating the current status of the node. Potential values: `running`, `provisioning`, `errored`.
- The base URL of the cluster's Kubernetes API server
- The public IPv4 address of the cluster's Kubernetes API server
- The range of IP addresses in the overlay network of the Kubernetes cluster, in CIDR notation
- The range of assignable IP addresses for services running in the Kubernetes cluster, in CIDR notation
- An array of tags applied to the Kubernetes cluster. All clusters are automatically tagged `k8s` and `k8s:$K8S_CLUSTER_ID`.
- When the Kubernetes cluster was created, in ISO8601 combined date and time format
- When the Kubernetes cluster was last updated, in ISO8601 combined date and time format
- A list of node pools available inside the cluster

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster get <id|name> [flags]

Aliases:
  get, g

Examples:
The following example retrieve details about a Kubernetes cluster named `example-cluster`: doctl kubernetes cluster get example-cluster

Flags:
      --format ID   Columns for output in a comma-separated list. Possible values: ID, `Name`, `Region`, `Version`, `AutoUpgrade`, `HAControlPlane`, `Status`, `Endpoint`, `IPv4`, `ClusterSubnet`, `ServiceSubnet`, `Tags`, `Created`, `Updated`, `NodePools`, `Autoscaler.UtilizationThreshold`, `Autoscaler.UnneededTime`, `Autoscaler.Expanders`, `RoutingAgent`, `AmdGpuDevicePlugin`, `AmdGpuDeviceMetricsExporterPlugin`.
  -h, --help        help for get
      --no-header   Return raw data with no headers

      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")

The commands under `doctl kubernetes cluster kubeconfig` are used to manage Kubernetes cluster credentials on your local machine. The credentials are used as authentication contexts with `kubectl`, the Kubernetes command-line interface.

Usage:

Aliases:
  kubeconfig, kubecfg, k8scfg, config, cfg

- A unique ID for the cluster

options.description: Enables auto-scaling on the node pool
The number of nodes in the node pool (required)
A label in key=value notation to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional labels. An existing label is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.
The maximum number of nodes in the node pool when autoscaling is enabled
The minimum number of nodes in the node pool when autoscaling (auto_scale) is enabled. If auto_scale is set to false, the default value will be 0. Scale-to-zero is not supported.
The name of the node pool (required)
The size of the nodes in the node pool. Use the `doctl kubernetes options sizes` command for a list of possible values. (required)
A tag to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional tags. An existing tag is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.

Taint in key=value:effect notation to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional taints. Set to an empty string ("") to clear all taints. An existing taint is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool create
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates a new node pool for the specified cluster. The command requires values for the `--name`, `--size`, and `--count` flags to create a node pool. You can also specify that you'd like to enable autoscaling and set minimum and maximum node poll sizes.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool create <cluster-id|cluster-name> [flags]

Aliases:
  create, c

Examples:
The following example creates a node pool named `example-pool` in a cluster named `example-cluster`: doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool create example-cluster --name example-pool --size s-1vcpu-2gb --count 3 --taint "key1=value1:NoSchedule" --taint "key2:NoExecute"

Flags:
      --auto-scale               Enables auto-scaling on the node pool
      --count int                The number of nodes in the node pool (required)
  -h, --help                     help for create
      --label strings            A label in key=value notation to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional labels. An existing label is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.
      --max-nodes int            The maximum number of nodes in the node pool when autoscaling is enabled
      --min-nodes int            The minimum number of nodes in the node pool when autoscaling (auto_scale) is enabled. If auto_scale is set to false, the default value will be 0. Scale-to-zero is not supported.
      --name string              The name of the node pool (required)
      --size size                The size of the nodes in the node pool. Use the `doctl kubernetes options sizes` command for a list of possible values. (required)
      --tag strings              A tag to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional tags. An existing tag is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.
      --taint key=value:effect   Taint in key=value:effect notation to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional taints. Set to an empty string ("") to clear all taints. An existing taint is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool replace-node
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Deletes the specified node in the specified node pool, and then creates a new node in its place. This is useful if you suspect a node has entered an undesired state. By default, the deletion happens gracefully and Kubernetes drains the node of any pods before deleting it.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool replace-node <cluster-id|cluster-name> <pool-id|pool-name> <node-id> [flags]

Examples:
The following example replaces a node named `example-node` in a node pool named `example-pool`: doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool replace-node example-cluster example-pool example-node

Flags:
  -f, --force        Replaces node without confirmation prompt
  -h, --help         help for replace-node
      --skip-drain   Skips draining the node before replacement

      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.raw_help_text:

Aliases:
  update, u

The following example updates a node pool named `example-pool` in a cluster named `example-cluster`: doctl kubernetes cluster node-pool update example-cluster example-pool --count 5 --taint "key1=value1:NoSchedule" --taint "key2:NoExecute"

      --min-nodes int            The minimum number of nodes in the node pool when autoscaling is enabled
      --name string              The name of the node pool

      --taint key=value:effect   Taint in key=value:effect notation to apply to the node pool. Repeat this flag to specify additional taints. Set to an empty string ("") to clear all taints. An existing taint is removed from the node pool if it is not specified by any flag.

options.description: Indicates whether the cluster automatically upgrades to new patch releases during its maintenance window. To enable automatic upgrade, use --auto-upgrade=true.
A comma-separated list of allowed addresses that can access the control plane.
Creates the cluster with amd gpu device metrics exporter plugin installed. Defaults to false. To enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-metrics-exporter-plugin=true.
Creates the cluster with amd gpu device plugin installed. Defaults to true for clusters with AMD GPUs and otherwise false. To always enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-plugin=true.
options.default: true for clusters with AMD GPUs

options.description: Creates the cluster with control plane firewall enabled. Defaults to false. To enable the control plane firewall, supply --enable-control-plane-firewall=true.
Creates the cluster with routing-agent enabled. Defaults to false. To enable routing-agent, supply --routing-agent=true.

Customizes expanders used by cluster-autoscaler. The autoscaler will apply each expander from the provided comma-separated list to narrow down the selection of node types created to scale up, until either a single node type is left, or the list of expanders is exhausted. Available expanders: random, least-waste, priority. If this value is empty, autoscaler will use its default expanders. To unset expander customization, pass an empty string.
Enables the highly-available control plane for the cluster

Sets the beginning of the four hour maintenance window for the cluster. Syntax is in the format: 'day=HH:MM', where time is in UTC. Day can be: any, `monday`, `tuesday`, `wednesday`, `thursday`, `friday`, `saturday`, `sunday`. (default "any=00:00")

The unneed time for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-unneeded-time. It defines how long a node should be unneeded before it is eligible for scale down. To set the scale-down-unneeded-time to a minute and 30 seconds for example, pass the string '1m30s'.

The threshold value for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-utilization-threshold. It is the maximum value between the sum of CPU requests and sum of memory requests of all pods running on the node divided by node's corresponding allocatable resource, below which a node can be considered for scale down. To set the scale-down-utilization-threshold to 50%, pass the floating point value 0.5.
Sets the current kubectl context to that of the new cluster (default true)
A comma-separated list of tags to apply to the cluster. This removes other user-provided tags from the cluster if they are not specified in this argument.
Updates the cluster in your kubeconfig (default true)

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster update
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Updates the configuration values for a Kubernetes cluster. The cluster must be referred to by its name or ID. Use the `doctl kubernetes cluster list` command to get a list of clusters on your account.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster update <id|name> [flags]

Aliases:
  update, u

Examples:
The following example updates a cluster named `example-cluster` to enable automatic upgrades and sets the maintenance window to `saturday=02:00`: doctl kubernetes cluster update example-cluster --auto-upgrade --maintenance-window saturday=02:00

Flags:
      --auto-upgrade --auto-upgrade=true                   Indicates whether the cluster automatically upgrades to new patch releases during its maintenance window. To enable automatic upgrade, use --auto-upgrade=true.
      --cluster-name string                                Specifies a new cluster name
      --control-plane-firewall-allowed-addresses strings   A comma-separated list of allowed addresses that can access the control plane.
      --enable-amd-gpu-device-metrics-exporter-plugin      Creates the cluster with amd gpu device metrics exporter plugin installed. Defaults to false. To enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-metrics-exporter-plugin=true.
      --enable-amd-gpu-device-plugin                       Creates the cluster with amd gpu device plugin installed. Defaults to true for clusters with AMD GPUs and otherwise false. To always enable it, supply --enable-amd-gpu-device-plugin=true.
      --enable-control-plane-firewall                      Creates the cluster with control plane firewall enabled. Defaults to false. To enable the control plane firewall, supply --enable-control-plane-firewall=true.
      --enable-routing-agent                               Creates the cluster with routing-agent enabled. Defaults to false. To enable routing-agent, supply --routing-agent=true.
      --expanders strings                                  Customizes expanders used by cluster-autoscaler. The autoscaler will apply each expander from the provided comma-separated list to narrow down the selection of node types created to scale up, until either a single node type is left, or the list of expanders is exhausted. Available expanders: random, least-waste, priority. If this value is empty, autoscaler will use its default expanders. To unset expander customization, pass an empty string.
      --ha                                                 Enables the highly-available control plane for the cluster
  -h, --help                                               help for update
      --maintenance-window any                             Sets the beginning of the four hour maintenance window for the cluster. Syntax is in the format: 'day=HH:MM', where time is in UTC. Day can be: any, `monday`, `tuesday`, `wednesday`, `thursday`, `friday`, `saturday`, `sunday`. (default "any=00:00")
      --scale-down-unneeded-time string                    The unneed time for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-unneeded-time. It defines how long a node should be unneeded before it is eligible for scale down. To set the scale-down-unneeded-time to a minute and 30 seconds for example, pass the string '1m30s'.
      --scale-down-utilization-threshold string            The threshold value for the cluster autoscaler's scale-down-utilization-threshold. It is the maximum value between the sum of CPU requests and sum of memory requests of all pods running on the node divided by node's corresponding allocatable resource, below which a node can be considered for scale down. To set the scale-down-utilization-threshold to 50%, pass the floating point value 0.5.
      --set-current-context                                Sets the current kubectl context to that of the new cluster (default true)
      --surge-upgrade                                      Enables surge-upgrade for the cluster
      --tag strings                                        A comma-separated list of tags to apply to the cluster. This removes other  user-provided tags from the cluster if they are not specified in this argument.
      --update-kubeconfig                                  Updates the cluster in your kubeconfig (default true)

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes cluster
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The commands under `doctl kubernetes cluster` are for the management of Kubernetes clusters.

A typical workflow is to use `doctl kubernetes cluster create` to create the cluster on DigitalOcean's infrastructure, then call `doctl kubernetes cluster kubeconfig` to configure `kubectl` to connect to the cluster. You are then able to use `kubectl` to create and manage workloads.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes cluster [command]

Aliases:
  cluster, clusters, c

Available Commands:
  create                    Create a Kubernetes cluster
  delete                    Delete Kubernetes clusters 
  delete-selective          Delete a Kubernetes cluster and selectively delete resources associated with it
  get                       Retrieve details about a Kubernetes cluster
  get-upgrades              Retrieve a list of available Kubernetes version upgrades
  kubeconfig                Display commands for managing your local kubeconfig
  list                      Retrieve the list of Kubernetes clusters for your account
  list-associated-resources Retrieve DigitalOcean resources associated with a Kubernetes cluster
  node-pool                 Display commands for managing node pools
  registry                  Display commands for integrating clusters with docr
  update                    Update a Kubernetes cluster's configuration
  upgrade                   Upgrades a cluster to a new Kubernetes version

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for cluster

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

Use "doctl kubernetes cluster [command] --help" for more information about a command.

subcommands.name: doctl kubernetes
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The commands under `doctl kubernetes` are for managing Kubernetes clusters and viewing configuration options relating to clusters.

A typical workflow is to use `doctl kubernetes cluster create` to create the cluster on DigitalOcean's infrastructure, then call `doctl kubernetes cluster kubeconfig` to configure `kubectl` to connect to the cluster. You are then able to use `kubectl` to create and manage workloads.

The commands under `doctl kubernetes options` retrieve values used while creating clusters, such as the list of regions where cluster creation is supported.

Usage:
  doctl kubernetes [command]

Aliases:
  kubernetes, kube, k8s, k

Available Commands:
  1-click     Display commands that pertain to kubernetes 1-click applications
  cluster     Display commands for managing Kubernetes clusters
  options     List possible option values for use inside Kubernetes commands

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for kubernetes

Global Flags:

subcommands.name: doctl monitoring alert create
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates a new alert policy. You can create policies that monitor various metrics of your Droplets and send you alerts when a metric exceeds a specified threshold.
	
	For example, you can create a policy that monitors a Droplet's CPU usage and triggers an alert when the Droplet's CPU usage exceeds more than 80% for more than 10 minutes.
	
	For a full list of policy types you can set up, see our API documentation: https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/api-reference/#operation/monitoring_create_alertPolicy

Usage:
  doctl monitoring alert create [flags]

Examples:
The following example creates an alert policy that sends an email to `admin@example.com` whenever the memory usage on the listed Droplets (entities) exceeds 80% for more than five minutes: doctl monitoring alert create --type "v1/insights/droplet/memory_utilization_percent" --compare GreaterThan --value 80 --window 5m --entities 386734086,191669331 --emails admin@example.com

Flags:
      --compare GreaterThan                                                    The comparator of the alert policy. Possible values: GreaterThan or `LessThan`
      --description string                                                     A description of the alert policy
      --emails strings                                                         Email address to send alerts to
      --enabled                                                                Enables the alert policy (default true)
      --entities strings                                                       Resources to apply the alert against, such as a Droplet ID.
  -h, --help                                                                   help for create
      --slack-channels production-alerts                                       A Slack channel to send alerts to. For example, production-alerts
      --slack-urls https://hooks.slack.com/services/T1234567/AAAAAAAA/ZZZZZZ   A Slack webhook URL to send alerts to, for example, https://hooks.slack.com/services/T1234567/AAAAAAAA/ZZZZZZ.
      --tags strings                                                           Tags to apply the alert policy to. If set to a tag, all Droplet with that tag are monitored by the alert policy.
      --type v1/insights/droplet/memory_utilization_percent                    The type of alert policy. For example,v1/insights/droplet/memory_utilization_percent alerts on the percent of memory utilization. For a full list of alert types, see https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/api-reference/#operation/monitoring_create_alertPolicy
      --value DropletCPUUtilizationPercent                                     The threshold value of the alert policy to compare against. For example, if the alert policy is of type DropletCPUUtilizationPercent and the value is set to `80`, an alert is triggered if the Droplet's CPU usage exceeds 80% for the specified window.
      --window 5m                                                              The amount of time the resource must exceed the threshold value before an alert is triggered. Possible values: 5m, `10m`, `30m`, or `1h` (default "5m")

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")

  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl monitoring alert
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The commands under `doctl monitoring alert` are for managing alert policies.

You can apply alert policies to resources in order to receive alerts on resource consumption. 
			
If you'd like to alert on the uptime of a specific URL or IP address, use `doctl monitoring uptime alert` instead

Usage:
  doctl monitoring alert [command]

Aliases:
  alert, alerts, a

Available Commands:
  create      Create an alert policy
  delete      Delete an alert policy
  get         Retrieve information about an alert policy
  list        List all alert policies
  update      Update an alert policy

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for alert

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

Use "doctl monitoring alert [command] --help" for more information about a command.

The period of time the threshold must be exceeded to trigger an alert. Possible values: 2m, `3m`, `5m`, `10m`, `15m`, `30m`, `1h` (required)

A Slack webhook URL to send alerts to, for example, https://hooks.slack.com/services/T1234567/AAAAAAAA/ZZZZZZ.

The metric to alert on. Possible values: latency, `down`, `down_global`, `ssl_expiry` (required)

subcommands.name: doctl monitoring uptime alert create
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates an alert policy for an uptime check.
	
	You can create an alert policy based on the following metrics: 
	
	- `latency`: Alerts on the response latency. `--threshold` value is an integer representing milliseconds.
	- `down`: Alerts on whether the endpoints registers as down from any of the configured regions. No `--threshold` value is necessary.
	- `down_global`: Alerts on a target registering as down globally. No `--threshold` value is necessary.
	- `ssl_expiry`: Alerts on an SSL certificate expiring within the set threshold of days. `--threshold` value is an integer representing days.

Usage:
  doctl monitoring uptime alert create <uptime-check-id> [flags]

Aliases:
  create, c

Examples:
The following example creates an alert for an uptime check with an ID of f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6. The alert triggers if the endpoint's latency exceed 500ms for more than two minutes: doctl monitoring uptime alert create f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6 --name "Example Alert" --type latency --threshold 100 --comparison greater_than --period 2m --emails "admin@example.com"

Flags:
      --comparison greater_than                                                A comparison operator used against the alert's threshold. Possible values: greater_than or `less_than`
      --emails strings                                                         Emails addresses to send alerts. The addresses must be associated with your DigitalOcean account
      --format ID                                                              Columns for output in a comma-separated list. Possible values: ID, `Name`, `Type`, `Threshold`, `Comparison`, `Period`, `Emails`, `Slack Channels`.
  -h, --help                                                                   help for create
      --name string                                                            The name of the alert (required)
      --no-header                                                              Return raw data with no headers
      --period 2m                                                              The period of time the threshold must be exceeded to trigger an alert. Possible values: 2m, `3m`, `5m`, `10m`, `15m`, `30m`, `1h` (required)
      --slack-channels production-alerts                                       Slack channels to send alerts to, for example, production-alerts. Must be used with the `--slack-urls` flag.
      --slack-urls https://hooks.slack.com/services/T1234567/AAAAAAAA/ZZZZZZ   A Slack webhook URL to send alerts to, for example, https://hooks.slack.com/services/T1234567/AAAAAAAA/ZZZZZZ.
      --threshold int                                                          The threshold at which to trigger the alert. The specific threshold is dependent on the alert type.
      --type latency                                                           The metric to alert on. Possible values: latency, `down`, `down_global`, `ssl_expiry` (required)

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl monitoring uptime alert
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The sub-commands of `doctl monitoring uptime alert` manage your uptime alerts.

DigitalOcean Uptime Alerts provide the ability to monitor your endpoints from around the world,
and alert you when they're slow, unavailable, or SSL certificates are expiring.

In order to set up uptime alerts, you must first set up an uptime check. Uptime checks monitor and track the status of an endpoint while alerts notify you of status changes based on the thresholds you set.

Usage:
  doctl monitoring uptime alert [command]

Aliases:
  alert, alerts

Available Commands:
  create      Create an uptime alert
  delete      Delete an uptime alert
  get         Get uptime alert
  list        List uptime alerts
  update      Update an uptime alert

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for alert

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

Use "doctl monitoring uptime alert [command] --help" for more information about a command.

subcommands.name: doctl monitoring uptime create
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates an uptime check on your account. Uptime checks monitor any endpoint that is accessible over HTTP, HTTPS, ping (ICMP).
	
	You can use this check to set up an alert policy using the `doctl monitoring uptime alert` commands.

Usage:
  doctl monitoring uptime create <uptime-check-name> [flags]

Aliases:
  create, c

Examples:
The following example creates an uptime check that monitors the URL, `example.com` from the eastern and western regions of the Unites States: doctl monitoring uptime create --target https://example.com --type https --regions us_east,us_west --enabled true

Flags:
      --enabled           Whether or not the uptime check is enabled. Defaults to true (default true)
      --format ID         Columns for output in a comma-separated list. Possible values: ID, `Name`, `Type`, `Target`, `Regions`, `Enabled`.
  -h, --help              help for create
      --no-header         Return raw data with no headers
      --regions us_east   A comma-separated list of regions to monitor the target from. Possible values: us_east, `us_west`, `eu_west`, `se_asia`. Defaults to `us_east` (default [us_east])
      --target string     A valid URL to monitor (required)
      --type ping         The protocol to use to monitor the target URL. Possible values: ping, `http`, `https`. Defaults to either `http` or `https`, depending on the URL target provided

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl monitoring uptime update
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Updates an uptime check on your account.

All of these flags are required. Uptime checks cannot be disabled via `doctl`. You can only disable them using the control panel or the public API.

Usage:
  doctl monitoring uptime update <uptime-check-id> [flags]

Aliases:
  update, u

Examples:
The following example updates the name, target, type, and regions of an uptime check: doctl monitoring uptime update f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6 --name example --target https://example.com --type https --regions us_east,us_west

Flags:
      --format ID         Columns for output in a comma-separated list. Possible values: ID, `Name`, `Type`, `Target`, `Regions`, `Enabled`.
  -h, --help              help for update
      --name string       A name for the check (required)
      --no-header         Return raw data with no headers
      --regions us_east   A comma-separated list of regions to monitor the target from. Possible values: us_east, `us_west`, `eu_west`, `se_asia`. Defaults to `us_east` (required) (default [us_east])
      --target string     A valid URL to monitor (required)
      --type ping         The protocol to use to monitor the target URL. Possible values: ping, `http`, `https`. Defaults to either `http` or `https`, depending on the URL target provided (required)

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint

      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command

subcommands.name: doctl projects create
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates a new project in your account.

Projects allow you to organize your DigitalOcean resources (like Droplets, Spaces, load balancers, domains, and floating IPs) into groups that fit the way you work. You can create projects that align with the applications, environments, and clients that you host on DigitalOcean.

Usage:
  doctl projects create [flags]

Aliases:
  create, c

Examples:
The following example creates a project named `Example Project` with the purpose "Frontend development": doctl projects create --name "Example Project" --purpose "Frontend development"

Flags:
      --description string   A description of the project
      --environment enum     The environment in which your project resides. Possible enum values: `Development`, `Staging`, `Production`.
      --format ID            Columns for output in a comma-separated list. Possible values: ID, `OwnerUUID`, `OwnerID`, `Name`, `Description`, `Purpose`, `Environment`, `IsDefault`, `CreatedAt`, `UpdatedAt`.
  -h, --help                 help for create
      --name string          The project's name (required)
      --no-header            Return raw data with no headers
      --purpose string       The project's purpose (required)

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl projects resources assign
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Assign one or more resources to a project by specifying the resource's uniform resource name ("URN").

A valid URN has the format: `do:resource_type:resource_id`. For example:

subcommands.name: doctl projects
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The subcommands of `doctl projects` allow you to create, manage, and assign resources to your projects.

Projects allow you to organize your DigitalOcean resources (like Droplets, Spaces, load balancers, domains, and floating IPs) into groups that fit the way you work. You can create projects that align with the applications, environments, and clients that you host on DigitalOcean.

Usage:
  doctl projects [command]

Available Commands:
  create      Create a new project
  delete      Delete the specified project
  get         Retrieve details for a specific project
  list        List existing projects
  resources   Manage resources assigned to a project
  update      Update an existing project

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for projects

Global Flags:

  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint

      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl registries docker-config
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Outputs a JSON-formatted Docker configuration that you can use to configure a Docker client to authenticate with your private container registry. This configuration is useful for configuring third-party tools that need access to your registry.

By default this command generates read-only credentials. Use the `--read-write` flag to generate credentials that can push. The configuration produced by this command contains a DigitalOcean API token that can be used to access your account and should be treated as sensitive information.

Usage:
  doctl registries docker-config <registry-name> [flags]

Aliases:
  docker-config, config

Examples:
The following example generates a Docker configuration for a registry named `example-registry` and uses the `--expiry-seconds` to set the credentials to expire after one day: doctl registries docker-config example-registry --expiry-seconds=86400

Flags:
      --expiry-seconds int   The length of time the registry credentials are valid for, in seconds. By default, the credentials do not expire.

subcommands.name: doctl registries kubernetes-manifest
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Outputs a YAML-formatted Kubernetes secret manifest that can be used to grant a Kubernetes cluster pull access to your private container registry.

By default, the secret manifest is applied to all the namespaces for the Kubernetes cluster using the DOSecret operator. The DOSecret operator is available on clusters running version 1.15.12-do.2 or greater. For older clusters, or to restrict the secret to a specific namespace, use the `--namespace` flag.

You can redirect the command's output to a file to save the manifest for later use or pipe it directly to `kubectl` to create the secret in your cluster:

    doctl registries kubernetes-manifest example-registry | kubectl apply -f -

Usage:
  doctl registries kubernetes-manifest <registry-name> [flags]

Aliases:
  kubernetes-manifest, k8s

Examples:
The following example generates a secret manifest for a registry named `example-registry` and applies it to the `kube-system` namespace: doctl registries kubernetes-manifest example-registry --namespace=kube-system

Flags:
  -h, --help               help for kubernetes-manifest
      --name string        The secret's name. Defaults to the registry name prefixed with "registry-"
      --namespace string   The Kubernetes namespace to hold the secret (default "kube-system")

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name

subcommands.name: doctl registry docker-config
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Outputs a JSON-formatted Docker configuration that you can use to configure a Docker client to authenticate with your private container registry. This configuration is useful for configuring third-party tools that need access to your registry. For configuring your local Docker client use `doctl registry login` instead, as it preserves the configuration of any other registries you have authenticated to.

By default this command generates read-only credentials. Use the `--read-write` flag to generate credentials that can push. The configuration produced by this command contains a DigitalOcean API token that can be used to access your account and should be treated as sensitive information.

Usage:
  doctl registry docker-config [flags]

Aliases:
  docker-config, config

Examples:
The following example generates a Docker configuration for a registry named `example-registry` and uses the `--expiry-seconds` to set the credentials to expire after one day: doctl registry docker-config example-registry --expiry-seconds=86400

Flags:
      --expiry-seconds int   The length of time the registry credentials are valid for, in seconds. By default, the credentials do not expire.
  -h, --help                 help for docker-config
      --read-write           Generates credentials that can push to your registry

subcommands.name: doctl registry kubernetes-manifest
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Outputs a YAML-formatted Kubernetes secret manifest that can be used to grant a Kubernetes cluster pull access to your private container registry.

By default, the secret manifest is applied to all the namespaces for the Kubernetes cluster using the DOSecret operator. The DOSecret operator is available on clusters running version 1.15.12-do.2 or greater. For older clusters, or to restrict the secret to a specific namespace, use the `--namespace` flag.

You can redirect the command's output to a file to save the manifest for later use or pipe it directly to `kubectl` to create the secret in your cluster:

    doctl registry kubernetes-manifest | kubectl apply -f -

Usage:
  doctl registry kubernetes-manifest [flags]

Aliases:
  kubernetes-manifest, k8s

Examples:
The following example generates a secret manifest for a registry named `example-registry` and applies it to the `kube-system` namespace: doctl registry kubernetes-manifest example-registry --namespace=kube-system

Flags:
  -h, --help               help for kubernetes-manifest
      --name string        The secret's name. Defaults to the registry name prefixed with "registry-"
      --namespace string   The Kubernetes namespace to hold the secret (default "kube-system")

  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")

      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl serverless activations get
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Retrieve the activation record for a previously invoked function. You can limit output to the result
or the logs.  The `doctl serverless activation logs` command has additional advanced capabilities for retrieving
logs.

Usage:
  doctl serverless activations get [<activationId>] [flags]

Examples:
The following example retrieves the results for the most recent activation of a function named `yourFunction`: doctl serverless activations get --function yourFunction --last --result

Flags:
  -f, --function string   Retrieve activations for a specific function.
  -h, --help              help for get
  -l, --last              Retrieve the most recent activation (default). Does not return activations for web-invoked functions.
  -g, --logs              Retrieve only the logs, stripped of time stamps and stream identifier.
  -q, --quiet             Suppress the last activation information header.
  -r, --result            Retrieve only the resulting output of a function.
  -s, --skip int          Exclude a specified number of activations from the returned list, starting with the most recent.

subcommands.name: doctl serverless activations list
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Use `doctl serverless activations list` to list the activation records that are present in the cloud for previously
invoked functions.

Usage:
  doctl serverless activations list [<function_name>] [flags]

Aliases:
  list, ls

Examples:
The following example lists all of the activations for a function named `yourFunction` since January 1, 2023: doctl serverless activations list --function yourFunction --since 1672549200000

Flags:
      --count             Return only the total number of activations.
      --format Datetime   Columns for output in a comma-separated list. Possible values: Datetime, `Status`, `Kind`, `Version`, `ActivationID`, `Start`, `Wait`, `Duration`, `Function`.
  -f, --full              Include the full activation description.
  -h, --help              help for list
  -l, --limit int         Limit the number of activations returned to the specified amount. Default: 30, Maximum: 200 (default 30)
      --no-header         Return raw data with no headers
      --since int         Retrieve activations invoked after the specified date-time, in UNIX timestamp format measured in milliseconds.
  -s, --skip int          Exclude a specified number of activations from the returned list, starting with the most recent.
      --upto int          Retrieve activations invoked before the specified date-time; in UNIX timestamp format measured in milliseconds.

Global Flags:

  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")

  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl serverless connect
subcommands.raw_help_text:
This command connects `doctl serverless` support to a functions namespace of your choice.
The optional argument should be a (complete or partial) match to a namespace label or id.
If there is no argument, all namespaces are matched.  If the result is exactly one namespace,
you are connected to it.  If there are multiple namespaces, you have an opportunity to choose
the one you want from a dialog.  Use `doctl serverless namespaces` to create, delete, and
list your namespaces.

Usage:
  doctl serverless connect [<hint>] [flags]

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for connect

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint

      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.name: doctl serverless deploy init
subcommands.raw_help_text:
At any time you can use `doctl serverless deploy` to upload the contents of a functions project in your file system for
testing in your serverless namespace.  The project must be organized in the fashion expected by an App Platform Functions
component.  The `doctl serverless init` command will create a properly organized directory for you to work in.

Usage:
  doctl serverless deploy <directory> [flags]

Flags:
      --apihost string     API host to use
      --auth string        OpenWhisk auth token to use
      --build-env string   Path to build-time environment file
      --env string         Path to runtime environment file
      --exclude string     Functions and/or packages to exclude
  -h, --help               help for deploy
      --include string     Functions and/or packages to include
      --incremental        Deploy only changes since last deploy
      --insecure           Ignore SSL Certificates
      --remote-build       Run builds remotely
      --verbose-build      Display build details
      --verbose-zip        Display start/end of zipping phase for each function
      --yarn               Use yarn instead of npm for node builds

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name

      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

subcommands.raw_help_text:
Invokes a function in your functions namespace.
You can provide inputs and inspect outputs.

Usage:
  doctl serverless functions invoke <functionName> [flags]

Examples:
The following example invokes a function named "example/helloWorld" with the parameters `name:John,place:NY`: doctl serverless functions invoke example/helloWorld --param name:John,place:NY

Flags:
  -f, --full                           Waits for the function to complete and then outputs the function's response along with its complete activation record. The record contains log information, duration time, and other information about the function's execution.
  -h, --help                           help for invoke
  -n, --no-wait                        Asynchronously invokes the function and does not wait for the result to be returned. An activation ID is returned in the response, instead.
  -p, --param name                     Key-value pairs of input parameters. For example, if your function takes two parameters called name and `place`, you would provide them as `name:John,place:NY`.
  -P, --param-file path/to/file.json   A path to a file containing parameter values in JSON format, such as path/to/file.json.
      --web                            Invokes the function as a web function and displays the result in your browser

subcommands.name: doctl serverless init
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The `doctl serverless init` command specifies a directory in your file system which will hold functions and
supporting artifacts while you're developing them.  This 'functions project' can be uploaded to your functions namespace for testing.
Later, after the functions project is committed to a `git` repository, you can create an app, or an app component, from it.

to choose your sample language for `doctl serverless init`.

Functions namespaces (in the cloud) contain the result of deploying packages and functions with `doctl serverless deploy`.
The subcommands of `doctl serverless namespaces` are used to manage multiple functions namespaces within your account.
Use `doctl serverless connect` with an explicit argument to connect to a specific namespace.  You are connected to one namespace at a time.

subcommands.name: doctl serverless undeploy
subcommands.raw_help_text:
This command removes functions, entire packages, or all functions and packages, from your function
namespace.  In general, deploying new content does not remove old content although it may overwrite it.
Use `doctl serverless undeploy` to effect removal.  The command accepts a list of functions or packages.
Functions should be listed in `pkgName/fnName` form, or `fnName` for a function not in any package.
The `--packages` flag causes arguments without slash separators to be interpreted as packages, in which case
the entire packages are removed.

Usage:
  doctl serverless undeploy [<package|function>...] [flags]

Flags:
      --all        remove all packages and functions
  -h, --help       help for undeploy
  -p, --packages   interpret simple name arguments as packages

Global Flags:

Type `doctl serverless watch <directory>` in a separate terminal window.  It will run until interrupted.
It will watch the directory (which should be one you initialized for serverless development) and will deploy
the contents to the cloud incrementally as it detects changes.

      --env string         Path to runtime environment file
      --exclude string     Functions and/or packages to exclude
  -h, --help               help for watch

      --insecure           Ignore SSL Certificates
      --remote-build       Run builds remotely

      --verbose-zip        Display start/end of zipping phase for each function
      --yarn               Use yarn instead of npm for node builds

subcommands.name: doctl serverless
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The `doctl serverless` commands provide an environment for developing, testing, and deploying serverless functions.
One or more local file system areas are employed, along with one or more 'functions namespaces' in the cloud.
A one-time install of the serverless software is needed (use `doctl serverless install` to install the software,
then `doctl serverless connect` to connect to a functions namespace associated with your account).
Other `doctl serverless` commands are used to develop, test, and deploy.

Usage:
  doctl serverless [command]

Aliases:
  serverless, sandbox, sbx, sls

Available Commands:
  activations  Retrieve activation records
  connect      Connects local serverless support to a functions namespace
  deploy       Deploy a functions project to your functions namespace
  functions    Work with the functions in your namespace
  get-metadata Obtain metadata of a functions project
  init         Initialize a 'functions project' directory in your local file system
  install      Installs the serverless support
  namespaces   Manage your functions namespaces
  status       Provide information about serverless support
  undeploy     Removes resources from your functions namespace
  uninstall    Removes the serverless support
  upgrade      Upgrades serverless support to match this version of doctl
  watch        Watch a functions project directory, deploying incrementally on change

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for serverless

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

Use "doctl serverless [command] --help" for more information about a command.

subcommands.name: doctl auth
subcommands.raw_help_text:
The `doctl auth` commands allow you to authenticate doctl for use with your DigitalOcean account using tokens that you generate in the control panel at https://cloud.digitalocean.com/account/api/tokens.

If you work with a just one account, call `doctl auth init` and supply the token when prompted. This creates an authentication context named `default`.

To switch between multiple DigitalOcean accounts, including team accounts, create named contexts using `doctl auth init --context <name>`, then providing the applicable token when prompted. This saves the token under the name you provide. To switch between contexts, use `doctl auth switch --context <name>`.

To remove accounts from the configuration file, run `doctl auth remove --context <name>`. This removes the token under the name you provide.

Usage:
  doctl auth [command]

Available Commands:
  init        Initialize doctl to use a specific account
  list        List available authentication contexts
  remove      Remove authentication contexts 
  switch      Switch between authentication contexts
  token       Display current authentication context API token

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for auth

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

Use "doctl auth [command] --help" for more information about a command.

- ID
- UUID (if applicable)
- Product name
- Description
- Group description
- Amount charged, in USD
- Duration of usage for the invoice period
- Duration unit of measurement, such as hours
- The start time of the invoice period, in ISO8601 combined date and time format
- The end time of the invoice period, in ISO8601 combined date and time format
- The project name the resource belongs to
- Category, such as "iaas"

Use the `doctl invoice list` command to find the UUID of the invoice to retrieve.

Usage:
  doctl invoice get <invoice-uuid> [flags]

subcommands.raw_help_text:
Retrieves a summary of an invoice, including the following details:

- The invoice's UUID
- The year and month of the billing period
- The total amount of the invoice, in USD
- The name of the user associated with the invoice
- The company associated with the invoice
- The email address associated with the invoice
- The amount of product usage charges contributing to the invoice
- The amount of overage charges contributing to the invoice, such as bandwidth overages
- The amount of taxes contributing to the invoice
- The amount of any credits or other adjustments contributing to the invoice

Use the `doctl invoice list` command to find the UUID of the invoice to retrieve.

Usage:
  doctl invoice summary <invoice-uuid> [flags]

subcommands.name: doctl completion bash
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Generate the autocompletion script for the bash shell.

This script depends on the 'bash-completion' package.
If it is not installed already, you can install it via your OS's package manager.

To load completions in your current shell session:

	source <(doctl completion bash)

To load completions for every new session, execute once:

#### Linux:

	doctl completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/doctl

#### macOS:

	doctl completion bash > $(brew --prefix)/etc/bash_completion.d/doctl

You will need to start a new shell for this setup to take effect.

Usage:
  doctl completion bash

Flags:
  -h, --help              help for bash
      --no-descriptions   disable completion descriptions

Global Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output
subcommands.description: Generate the autocompletion script for bash

subcommands.name: doctl completion zsh
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Generate the autocompletion script for the zsh shell.

If shell completion is not already enabled in your environment you will need
to enable it.  You can execute the following once:

	echo "autoload -U compinit; compinit" >> ~/.zshrc

To load completions in your current shell session:

	source <(doctl completion zsh)

To load completions for every new session, execute once:

#### Linux:

	doctl completion zsh > "${fpath[1]}/_doctl"

#### macOS:

	doctl completion zsh > $(brew --prefix)/share/zsh/site-functions/_doctl

You will need to start a new shell for this setup to take effect.

  doctl completion zsh [flags]

  -h, --help              help for zsh
      --no-descriptions   disable completion descriptions

  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token

      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name

      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)

name: doctl
raw_help_text:
doctl is a command line interface (CLI) for the DigitalOcean API.

Usage:
  doctl [command]

Manage DigitalOcean Resources:
  1-click         Display commands that pertain to 1-click applications
  account         Display commands that retrieve account details
  apps            Displays commands for working with apps
  compute         Display commands that manage infrastructure
  databases       Display commands that manage databases
  genai           Manage GenAI resources
  kubernetes      Displays commands to manage Kubernetes clusters and configurations
  monitoring      Display commands to manage monitoring
  network         Display commands that manage network products
  nfs             Display commands to manage network file storage
  projects        Manage projects and assign resources to them
  registries      Display commands for working with multiple container registries
  registry        Display commands for working with container registries
  serverless      Develop, test, and deploy serverless functions
  spaces          Display commands that manage DigitalOcean Spaces.
  vpcs            Display commands that manage VPCs

Configure doctl:
  auth            Display commands for authenticating doctl with an account
  version         Show the current version

View Billing:
  balance         Display commands for retrieving your account balance
  billing-history Display commands for retrieving your billing history
  invoice         Display commands for retrieving invoices for your account

Additional Commands:
  completion      Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell
  help            Help about any command

Flags:
  -t, --access-token string   API V2 access token
  -u, --api-url string        Override default API endpoint
  -c, --config string         Specify a custom config file (default "/root/.config/doctl/config.yaml")
      --context string        Specify a custom authentication context name
  -h, --help                  help for doctl
      --http-retry-max int    Set maximum number of retries for requests that fail with a 429 or 500-level error (default 5)
      --interactive           Enable interactive behavior. Defaults to true if the terminal supports it (default false)
  -o, --output string         Desired output format [text|json] (default "text")
      --trace                 Show a log of network activity while performing a command
  -v, --verbose               Enable verbose output

Use "doctl [command] --help" for more information about a command.
